<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Name">Name</span></h2>
<p>"Lenovo" is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Portmanteau&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Portmanteau (page does not exist)">portmanteau</a> of "Le-" (from Legend) and "novo", <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> <a href="/wiki/Ablative" title="Ablative" class="mw-redirect">ablative</a> for "new". The Chinese name (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Zh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Zh (page does not exist)">Template:Zh</a>) means "association" (as in "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Word_association&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Word association (page does not exist)">word association</a>") or "connected thinking" but can also imply <a href="/wiki/Creativity" title="Creativity">creativity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cam_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cam-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p>For the first 20 years of its existence, the company's English name was "Legend" (in Chinese 联想 <i>Lianxiang</i>). In 2002, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yang_Yuanqing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yang Yuanqing (page does not exist)">Yang Yuanqing</a> decided to abandon use of the Legend brand name in order to expand outside of China, as the "Legend" name was already in use by many other businesses worldwide, making it impossible to register in most jurisdictions. In April 2003, the company publicly announced its new name, "Lenovo", with a large media campaign involving huge outdoor billboards and primetime television ads. Lenovo spent 18 million RMB on an eight-week television advertising campaign. The billboards featured the Lenovo logo against blue sky with copy that read, "Transcendence depends on how you think." By the end of 2003, Lenovo had spent a total of 200 million RMB on <a href="/wiki/Rebranding" title="Rebranding">rebranding</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Book1_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Book1-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Founding_and_early_history">Founding and early history</span></h3>
<p>Liu founded Lenovo in 1984 with a group of ten engineers in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beijing (page does not exist)">Beijing</a> with 200,000 <a href="/wiki/Renminbi" title="Renminbi">yuan</a>. Lenovo officially states that it was founded on 1 November 1984. Lenovo's incorporation was approved by the Chinese government on the same day. Jia Xufu, one of the founders of Lenovo, indicates the first meeting in preparation for starting the company was held on 17 October of the same year. Eleven people, the entirety of the initial staff, attended. Each of the founders were middle-aged members of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Institute_of_Computing_Technology,_Chinese_Academy_of_Sciences&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Institute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences (page does not exist)">Institute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences</a>. The 200,000 yuan used as start-up capital was approved by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Zeng_Maochao&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zeng Maochao (page does not exist)">Zeng Maochao</a>. The name for the company agreed upon at this meeting was the Chinese Academy of Sciences Computer Technology Research Institute New Technology Development Company.<sup id="cite_ref-Book1_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Book1-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>Their first significant effort, an attempt to import televisions, failed. The group rebuilt itself within a year by conducting quality checks on computers for new buyers. Lenovo soon started developing a circuit board that would allow IBM-compatible personal computers to process <a href="/wiki/Chinese_characters" title="Chinese characters">Chinese characters</a>. This product was Lenovo's first major success. Lenovo also tried and failed to market a digital watch. Liu said, "Our management team often differed on which commercial road to travel. This led to big discussions, especially between the engineering chief and myself. He felt that if the quality of the product was good, then it would sell itself. But I knew this was not true, that marketing and other factors were part of the eventual success of a product." Lenovo's early difficulties were compounded by the fact that its staff had little business experience. "We were mainly scientists and didn't understand the market", Liu said. "We just learned by trial-and-error, which was very interesting—but also very dangerous", said Liu. In 1990, Lenovo started to manufacture and market computers using its own brand name.<sup id="cite_ref-chief_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chief-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 1988, Lenovo placed its first advertisement seeking employees. The ad was placed on the front page of the <i>China Youth News</i>. Such ads were quite rare in China at this time. Out of 500 respondents, 280 were selected to take a written employment exam. 120 of these candidates were interviewed in person. Although interviewers initially only had authority to hire 16 people, 58 were given offers. These new hires included 18 people with graduate degrees, 37 with undergraduate degrees, and three students with no university-level education. Their average age was 26. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yang_Yuanqing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yang Yuanqing (page does not exist)">Yang Yuanqing</a> was among this group.<sup id="cite_ref-Book1_5-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Book1-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Liu_Chuanzhi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Liu Chuanzhi (page does not exist)">Liu Chuanzhi</a>, received government permission to open a subsidiary in Hong Kong and was allowed to move there along with five other employees. Liu's father, already in Hong Kong, furthered his son's ambitions through mentoring and facilitating loans. Liu moved to Hong Kong in 1988. In order to save money during this period, Liu and his co-workers walked instead of taking public transportation. In order to keep up appearances they rented hotel rooms for meetings.<sup id="cite_ref-Book1_5-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Book1-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="IPO_and_secondary_offerings">IPO and secondary offerings</span></h3>
<p>Lenovo became publicly traded after a 1994 Hong Kong listing that raised nearly US$30 million. Prior to its IPO, many analysts were optimistic about Lenovo. The company was praised for its good management, strong brand recognition, and growth potential. Analysts also worried about Lenovo's profitability. Lenovo's IPO was massively over-subscribed. On its first day of trading, the company's stock price hit a high of HK$2.07 and closed at HK$2.00. Proceeds from the offering were used to finance sales offices in Europe, North America, and Australia; expand and improve production and research and development; and increase working capital.
</p><p>When Lenovo was first listed, its managers thought the only purpose of going public was to raise capital. They had little understanding of the rules and responsibilities that went along with running a public company. Before Lenovo conducted its first secondary offering in 1997, Liu proudly announced the company's intent to mainland newspapers only to have its stock halted for two days by regulators to punish his statement. This occurred several times until Liu learned that he had to choose his words carefully in public. The first time Liu traveled to Europe on a "roadshow" to discuss his company's stock, he was shocked by the skeptical questions he was subjected to and felt offended. Liu later came to understand that he was accountable to shareholders. He said, "Before I only had one boss, but CAS never asked me anything. I relied on my own initiative to do things. We began to think about issues of credibility. Legend began to learn how to become a truly international company."<sup id="cite_ref-Book1_5-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Book1-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>In order to get capital to fund its continued growth, Lenovo issued another secondary offering of 50 million shares on the Hong Kong market in March 2000 and raised about US$212 million.<sup id="cite_ref-Book1_5-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Book1-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mary Ma, Lenovo's chief financial officer from 1990 to 2007, was in charge of investor relations. Under her leadership, Lenovo successfully integrated Western-style accountability into its corporate culture. Lenovo's emphasis on transparency earned it a reputation for the best corporate governance among mainland Chinese firms. All major issues regarding its board, management, major share transfers, and mergers and acquisitions were fairly and accurately reported. While Hong Kong listed firms were only required to issue financial reports twice per year, Lenovo followed the international norm of issuing quarterly reports. Lenovo created an audit committee and a compensation committee with non-management directors. The company started roadshows twice per year to meet institutional investors. Ma organized the first-ever investor relations conference held in Mainland China. The conference was held in Beijing in 2002 and televised on CCTV. Liu and Ma co-hosted the conference and both gave speeches on corporate governance.<sup id="cite_ref-Book1_5-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Book1-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mergers_and_acquisitions">Mergers and acquisitions</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="IBM_personal_computer_business">IBM personal computer business</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lenovo_ThinkPad_Logo.jpg" title="File:Lenovo ThinkPad Logo.jpg">File:Lenovo ThinkPad Logo.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The ThinkPad logo as shown on the ThinkPad x100e notebook computer.</div></div></div>
<p>Lenovo acquired <a href="/w/index.php?title=IBM&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="IBM (page does not exist)">IBM</a>'s personal computer business in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-sumner2005_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sumner2005-7">[7]</a></sup> Lenovo's acquisition of IBM's personal computer division accelerated access to foreign markets while improving both its branding and technology.<sup id="cite_ref-MW1_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MW1-8">[8]</a></sup> Lenovo paid <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Currency&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Currency (page does not exist)">Template:Currency</a> for IBM's computer business and assumed an additional US$500 million of IBM's debt. This acquisition made Lenovo the third-largest computer maker worldwide by volume.<sup id="cite_ref-People_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-People-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p><p>In regards to the purchase of IBM's personal computer division, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Liu_Chuanzhi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Liu Chuanzhi (page does not exist)">Liu Chuanzhi</a> said, "We benefited in three ways from the IBM acquisition. We got the ThinkPad brand, IBM's more advanced PC manufacturing technology and the company's international resources, such as its global sales channels and operation teams. These three elements have shored up our sales revenue in the past several years."<sup id="cite_ref-People_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-People-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p><p>IBM acquired an 18.9% shareholding in Lenovo in 2005 as part of Lenovo's purchase of IBM's personal computing division.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> Since then, IBM has steadily reduced its holdings of Lenovo stock. In July 2008, IBM's interest in Lenovo fell below the 5% threshold that mandates public disclosure.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although Lenovo acquired the right to use the IBM brand name for five years after its acquisition of IBM's personal computer business, Lenovo used it for only three years. On 7 December 2007, an event called "Lenovo Pride Day" was held. After words of encouragement from management, employees ceremoniously peeled the IBM logos off their ThinkPads and replaced them with Lenovo stickers.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cn (page does not exist)">Template:Cn</a>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Mobile_devices">Mobile devices</span></h4>
<p>Lenovo sold its smartphone and tablet division in 2008 for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Currency&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Currency (page does not exist)">Template:Currency</a> in order to focus on personal computers and then paid <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Currency&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Currency (page does not exist)">Template:Currency</a> to buy it back in November 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-China_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-China-12">[12]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, the mobile division ranked third in terms of unit share in China's mobile handset market.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> Lenovo invested <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Currency&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Currency (page does not exist)">Template:Currency</a> in a fund dedicated to providing seed funding for mobile application development for its LeGarden online <a href="/w/index.php?title=Digital_distribution_platform&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Digital distribution platform (page does not exist)">app store</a>. As of 2010, LeGarden had more than 1,000 programs available for the LePhone. At the same time, LeGarden counted 2,774 individual developers and 542 developer companies as members.<sup id="cite_ref-LeGarden_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LeGarden-14">[14]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lenovo entered the smartphone market in 2012 and quickly became the largest vendor of <a href="/wiki/Smartphone" title="Smartphone">smartphones</a> in Mainland China.<sup id="cite_ref-smartphones_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-smartphones-15">[15]</a></sup> Entry into the smartphone market was paired with a change of strategy from "the one-size-fits-all" to a diverse portfolio of devices.<sup id="cite_ref-einhorn2013_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-einhorn2013-16">[16]</a></sup>  These changes were driven by the popularity of Apple's <a href="/w/index.php?title=IPhone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="IPhone (page does not exist)">iPhone</a> and Lenovo's desire to increase its market share in mainland China. Lenovo passed Apple to become the No.&#160;2 provider of smartphones to the Chinese market in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-einhorn2013_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-einhorn2013-16">[16]</a></sup>  However, due to there being about 100 smartphone brands sold in China, this second only equated to a 10.4% market share.<sup id="cite_ref-einhorn2013_16-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-einhorn2013-16">[16]</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2012, Lenovo announced an investment of US$793 million in the construction of a mobile phone manufacturing and R&amp;D facility in <a href="/wiki/Wuhan" title="Wuhan">Wuhan</a>, China.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Joint_venture_with_NEC">Joint venture with NEC</span></h4>
<p>On January 27, 2011, Lenovo formed a joint venture to produce personal computers with Japanese electronics firm <a href="/wiki/NEC" title="NEC">NEC</a>. The companies said in a statement they will establish a new company called Lenovo NEC Holdings B.V., which will be registered in the Netherlands. NEC will receive US$175 million from Lenovo through the issuance of Lenovo's shares. Lenovo will own a 51% stake in the joint venture, while NEC will hold a 49% stake. Lenovo has a five-year option to expand its stake in the joint venture.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>This joint venture is intended to boost Lenovo's worldwide sales by expanding its presence in Japan, a key market for personal computers. NEC has spun off its personal computer business into the joint venture. As of 2010, NEC controlled about 20% of Japan's market for personal computers while Lenovo had a 5% share. Lenovo and NEC have also agreed to explore cooperating in other areas such as servers and tablet computers.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p><p>Roderick Lappin, chairman of the Lenovo-NEC joint venture, told the press that the two companies will expand their co-operation to include the joint development of tablet computers.<sup id="cite_ref-ET_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ET-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Medion">Medion</span></h4>
<p>In June 2011, Lenovo announced that it planned to acquire control of <a href="/wiki/Medion" title="Medion">Medion</a>, a German electronics manufacturing company. Lenovo said the acquisition would double its share of the German computer market, making it the third-largest vendor by sales (after <a href="/wiki/Acer_Inc." title="Acer Inc.">Acer</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hewlett-Packard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hewlett-Packard (page does not exist)">Hewlett-Packard</a>). The deal, which closed in the third quarter of the same year, was the first in which a Chinese company acquired a well-known German company.<sup id="cite_ref-Kraut_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kraut-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>This acquisition will give Lenovo 14% of the German computer market. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gerd_Brachmann&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gerd Brachmann (page does not exist)">Gerd Brachmann</a>, chairman of Medion, agreed to sell two-thirds of his 60 percent stake in the company. He will be paid in cash for 80 percent of the shares and will receive 20 percent in Lenovo stock. That would give him about one percent of Lenovo.<sup id="cite_ref-Kraut_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kraut-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="CCE">CCE</span></h4>
<p>In September 2012, Lenovo agreed to acquire the Brazil-based electronics company Digibras, which sells products under the brand-name CCE, for a base price of 300 million reals (US$148 million) in a combination of stock and cash and an additional 400 million reals dependent upon performance benchmarks.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> Prior to its acquisition of CCE, Lenovo already established a $30 million factory in Brazil, but Lenovo's management had felt that they needed a local partner to maximise regional growth. Lenovo cited their desire to take advantage of increased sales due to the 2014 World Cup that will be hosted by Brazil and the 2016 Summer Olympics and CCE's reputation for quality.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> Following the acquisition, Lenovo announced that its subsequent acquisitions would be concentrated in the areas of software and IT services.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Stoneware">Stoneware</span></h4>
<p>In September 2012, Lenovo agreed to acquire the United States-based software company Stoneware, in its first software acquisition. The transaction was expected to close by the end of 2012; no financial details have been disclosed.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> Lenovo said that the company was acquired in order to gain access to new technology and that Stoneware is not expected to significantly affect earnings. More specifically, Stoneware was acquired to further Lenovo's efforts to improve and expand its cloud-computing services. For the two years prior to its acquisition, Stoneware partnered with Lenovo to sell its software. During this period Stoneware's sales doubled.  Stoneware was founded in 2000. As of September 2012, Stoneware is based in Carmel, Indiana and has 67 employees.<sup id="cite_ref-Stoned_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stoned-28">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BW3_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BW3-29">[29]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="LenovoEMC">LenovoEMC</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:LenovoEMCSigning.jpg" title="File:LenovoEMCSigning.jpg">File:LenovoEMCSigning.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The signing ceremony for the LenovoEMC joint venture</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Lenovo and <a href="/wiki/EMC_Corporation" title="EMC Corporation">EMC</a> formed LenovoEMC as a joint venture to offer <a href="/wiki/Network_attached_storage" title="Network attached storage" class="mw-redirect">network attached storage</a> (NAS) solutions. LenovoEMC's products were formerly offered under the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iomega&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iomega (page does not exist)">Iomega</a> brand name. After the formation of LenovoEMC, Iomega ceased to exist as business unit. LenovoEMC's products are designed for small and medium sized that do not have the budgets for enterprise-class data storage. LenovoEMC is part of a broader partnership between the two companies announced in August 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-LENOVOEMC_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LENOVOEMC-30">[30]</a></sup> This partnership also includes an effort to develop x86-based servers and allowing Lenovo to act as an OEM for some EMC hardware. Lenovo is expected to benefit from the relatively high profit margins of the NAS market. LenovoEMC is part of Lenovo's Enterprise Products Group.<sup id="cite_ref-LENOVOEMCARS_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LENOVOEMCARS-31">[31]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-GROUP_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GROUP-32">[32]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Motorola">Motorola</span></h4>
<p>On 29 January 2014, Google announced it would sell <a href="/w/index.php?title=Motorola_Mobility&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Motorola Mobility (page does not exist)">Motorola Mobility</a> to Lenovo for US$2.91 billion in a cash-and-stock deal. Google will retain the Advanced Technologies &amp; Projects unit and all but 2000 of the company's patents. Lenovo had prominently disclosed its intent to enter the U.S. smartphone market. Yang Yuanqing stated that "the acquisition of such an iconic brand, innovative product portfolio and incredibly talented global team will immediately make Lenovo a strong global competitor in smartphones".<sup id="cite_ref-verge-lenovosale_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-verge-lenovosale-33">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-verge-bblenovo_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-verge-bblenovo-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Products_and_services">Products and services</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Smartphones_and_tablets">Smartphones and tablets</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:ThinkPad_Tablet_2.jpg" title="File:ThinkPad Tablet 2.jpg">File:ThinkPad Tablet 2.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The ThinkPad Tablet 2 from front and back.</div></div></div>
<p>Lenovo launched the <a href="/w/index.php?title=LePhone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="LePhone (page does not exist)">LePhone</a> in China in order to compete against other smart phones. These same phones are marketed as IdeaPhones outside of China
</p><p>As of January 2013, Lenovo only manufactures phones that use the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Android_(operating_system)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Android (operating system) (page does not exist)">Android</a> operating system from <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Google</a>. Numerous press reports indicated that Lenovo planned to release a phone running <a href="/w/index.php?title=Windows_Phone_8&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Windows Phone 8 (page does not exist)">Windows Phone 8</a>, According to JD Howard, a vice president at Lenovo's mobile division, the company would release a Windows Phone product if there is market demand.<sup id="cite_ref-Lumia_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lumia-35">[35]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lenovo has implemented an aggressive strategy to replace <a href="/wiki/Samsung_Electronics" title="Samsung Electronics">Samsung Electronics</a> as Mainland China market's top smartphone vendor. It has spent $793.5 million in Wuhan in order to build a plant that can produce 30 to 40 million phones per year. Data from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Analysys_International&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Analysys International (page does not exist)">Analysys International</a> shows that Lenovo experienced considerable growth in smartphone sales in China during 2012. Specifically, it saw its market share increase to 14.2% during 2012's third quarter, representing an increase when compared to 4.8% in the same quarter of 2011. IDC analysts said that Lenovo's success is due to its "aggressive ramping-up and improvements in channel partnerships." Analysys International analyst Wang Ying wrote, "Lenovo possesses an obvious advantage over rivals in terms of sales channels." The company's CEO, Yang Yuanqing, said, "Lenovo does not want to be the second player ... we want to be the best. Lenovo has the confidence to outperform Samsung and Apple, at least in the Chinese market." <sup id="cite_ref-TOM_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TOM-36">[36]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to IHS iSuppli, Lenovo was a top-three smartphone maker in China with a 16.5% market share in the first quarter of 2012. According to a May report released by IDC Lenovo ranks fourth in the global tablet market by volume.<sup id="cite_ref-PCMAG_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PCMAG-37">[37]</a></sup> As of November 2012, Lenovo was the second largest seller of mobile phones in China when measured by volume.<sup id="cite_ref-smartphones_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-smartphones-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2013, Lenovo CEO Yang Yuanqing indicated that the company had aimed to release smartphones in the United States within the next year. Later in October, Lenovo expressed interest in acquiring the Canadian smartphone maker <a href="/wiki/BlackBerry_Ltd" title="BlackBerry Ltd">BlackBerry Ltd</a>. However, its attempt was reportedly blocked by the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Canada" title="Government of Canada">Government of Canada</a>, citing security concerns due to the use of BlackBerry devices by prominent members of the government. An official stated that "we have been pretty consistent that the message is Canada is open to foreign investment and investment from China in particular but not at the cost of compromising national security".<sup id="cite_ref-verge-bblenovo_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-verge-bblenovo-34">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-verge-lenovousphones_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-verge-lenovousphones-38">[38]</a></sup> In January 2014, Lenovo announced a proposed deal to acquire <a href="/w/index.php?title=Motorola_Mobility&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Motorola Mobility (page does not exist)">Motorola Mobility</a> to bolster its plans for the U.S. market.<sup id="cite_ref-verge-lenovosale_33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-verge-lenovosale-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Smart_televisions">Smart televisions</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lenovo_A30_TV_Set_Top_Box.jpg" title="File:Lenovo A30 TV Set Top Box.jpg">File:Lenovo A30 TV Set Top Box.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A Lenovo A30 TV set top box</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In November 2011, Lenovo said it would soon unveil a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Smart_television&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Smart television (page does not exist)">smart television</a> product called LeTV, expected for release in the first quarter of 2012. "The PC, communications and TV industries are currently undergoing a “smart” transformation. In the future, users will have many smart devices and will desire an integrated experience of hardware, software and cloud services." Liu Jun, president of Lenovo's mobile-Internet and digital-home-business division.<sup id="cite_ref-TV_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TV-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Personal_and_business_computing">Personal and business computing</span></h3>
<p>While many argue that computing is entering a "post-PC era", Lenovo's CEO, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yang_Yuanqing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yang Yuanqing (page does not exist)">Yang Yuanqing</a>, believes that the personal computer is still relevant and that computing is really entering what he calls the "PC plus era". In order to avoid commodity pricing and compete against mobile devices, Yang has pushed Lenovo to pursue innovative new PC designs such as its popular IdeaPad Yoga products, ThinkPad Helix, and ThinkPad Twist. Lenovo has achieved significant success with this high-value strategy and it now controls more than 40% of the market for Windows computers priced above $900 in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-CNET21_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNET21-40">[40]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="ThinkPad">ThinkPad</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lenovo_ThinkPad_X1_Ultrabook.jpg" title="File:Lenovo ThinkPad X1 Ultrabook.jpg">File:Lenovo ThinkPad X1 Ultrabook.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A Lenovo ThinkPad X1 Ultrabook</div></div></div>
<p>ThinkPad is a line of business-oriented <a href="/wiki/Laptop_computer" title="Laptop computer" class="mw-redirect">laptop computers</a> known for their boxy black design, modeled after a traditional Japanese <a href="/wiki/Bento" title="Bento">lunchbox</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> ThinkPads were originally an <a href="/w/index.php?title=IBM&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="IBM (page does not exist)">IBM</a> product; they have been manufactured and sold by Lenovo since early 2005, following its acquisition of IBM's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Personal_computer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Personal computer (page does not exist)">personal computer</a> division. The ThinkPad has been used in space and is the only laptop certified for use on the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup>
</p><p>Shipments of Think-branded computers have doubled since Lenovo's takeover of the brand, with operating margins thought to be above 5%.<sup id="cite_ref-Econ1_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Econ1-43">[43]</a></sup> Lenovo has aggressively expanded the ThinkPad brand away from traditional laptop computers in favor of tablets and hybrid devices such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=ThinkPad_Helix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="ThinkPad Helix (page does not exist)">ThinkPad Helix</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=ThinkPad_Twist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="ThinkPad Twist (page does not exist)">ThinkPad Twist</a>.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="ThinkCentre">ThinkCentre</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
ThinkCentre is a line of business-oriented <a href="/wiki/Desktop_computer" title="Desktop computer">Desktop computers</a> which was introduced in 2003 by IBM and since has been produced and sold by Lenovo since 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-Lenovo_Company_History_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lenovo_Company_History-44">[44]</a></sup> ThinkCentre computers typically include mid-range to high-end processors, options for discrete graphics cards, and multi-monitor support.<sup id="cite_ref-Lenovo_-_ThinkCentre_Desktops_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lenovo_-_ThinkCentre_Desktops-45">[45]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Lenovo_-_ThinkCentre_Desktops_45-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lenovo_-_ThinkCentre_Desktops-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="ThinkServer">ThinkServer</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The ThinkServer product line began with the TS100 from Lenovo.<sup id="cite_ref-PCPro_-_ThinkServer_TS100_Review_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PCPro_-_ThinkServer_TS100_Review-46">[46]</a></sup> The server was developed under agreement with <a href="/w/index.php?title=IBM&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="IBM (page does not exist)">IBM</a>, by which Lenovo would produce single-socket and dual-socket servers based on IBM’s xSeries technology.<sup id="cite_ref-PCPro_-_ThinkServer_TS100_Review_46-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PCPro_-_ThinkServer_TS100_Review-46">[46]</a></sup> An additional feature of the server design was a support package aimed at small businesses.<sup id="cite_ref-PCPro_-_ThinkServer_TS100_Review_46-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PCPro_-_ThinkServer_TS100_Review-46">[46]</a></sup> The focus of this support package was to provide small businesses with software tools to ease the process of server management and reduce dependence on IT support.<sup id="cite_ref-Lenovo_Blogs_-_ThinkServer_Debut_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lenovo_Blogs_-_ThinkServer_Debut-47">[47]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="ThinkStation">ThinkStation</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The ThinkStation products from Lenovo are workstations designed for high-end computing. In 2008, Lenovo expanded the focus of its “THINK” brand to include workstations, with the ThinkStation S10 being the first model released.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="ThinkVision_displays">ThinkVision displays</span></h4>
<p>High-end computer displays are marketed under the ThinkVision name. ThinkVision displays share a common design language with other THINK devices such as the <a href="/wiki/ThinkPad" title="ThinkPad">ThinkPad</a> line of notebook computers and <a href="/wiki/ThinkCentre" title="ThinkCentre">ThinkCentre</a> desktops.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="IdeaPad">IdeaPad</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lenovo_IdeaPad.jpeg" title="File:Lenovo IdeaPad.jpeg">File:Lenovo IdeaPad.jpeg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A model with a Lenovo IdeaPad at a launch party in Japan.</div></div></div>
<p>The IdeaPad line of consumer-oriented <a href="/wiki/Laptop_computers" title="Laptop computers" class="mw-redirect">laptop computers</a> was introduced in January 2008. The IdeaPad is the result of Lenovo's own research and development; Unlike the ThinkPad line of notebooks, its design and branding were not inherited from IBM. The IdeaPad line's design language differs markedly from the <a href="/wiki/ThinkPad" title="ThinkPad">ThinkPad</a> and has a more consumer-focused look and feel.<sup id="cite_ref-IdeaPad_Consumer_Oriented_Design_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IdeaPad_Consumer_Oriented_Design-48">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup>
</p><p>In October 2012 the firm launched the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lenovo_IdeaPad_Yoga_13&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lenovo IdeaPad Yoga 13 (page does not exist)">IdeaPad Yoga 13</a>, a laptop running Microsoft Corp's Windows 8 that can be converted to a tablet PC by flipping the screen all the way backwards.<sup id="cite_ref-reuters_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reuters-50">[50]</a></sup> Lenovo has subsequently released the IdeaPad Yoga 11 running Windows RT and announced the IdeaPad Yoga 11S running Windows 8. Lenovo's Yoga products reflect the company's commitment to the "PC plus era" where innovative products allow Lenovo to resist commodity pricing of PCs.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="IdeaCentre">IdeaCentre</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lenovo_IdeaCentre_A720.jpg" title="File:Lenovo IdeaCentre A720.jpg">File:Lenovo IdeaCentre A720.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A Lenovo IdeaCentre all-in-one PC</div></div></div>
<p>All IdeaCentres are all-in-one machines, combining processor and monitor into a single unit.<sup id="cite_ref-Lenovo_IdeaCentre_Desktops_at_CES_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lenovo_IdeaCentre_Desktops_at_CES-51">[51]</a></sup> The desktops were described by HotHardware as being "uniquely designed".<sup id="cite_ref-Lenovo_IdeaCentre_Desktops_at_CES_51-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lenovo_IdeaCentre_Desktops_at_CES-51">[51]</a></sup> The first <a href="/w/index.php?title=IdeaCentre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="IdeaCentre (page does not exist)">IdeaCentre</a> <a href="/wiki/Desktop_computer" title="Desktop computer">desktop</a>, the IdeaCentre K210, was announced by Lenovo on June 30, 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-Lenovo_IdeaCentre_K210_-_TechCrunch_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lenovo_IdeaCentre_K210_-_TechCrunch-52">[52]</a></sup> While IdeaCentre was designed to be purely desktop models, influences of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=IdeaPad&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="IdeaPad (page does not exist)">IdeaPad</a> line were observed.<sup id="cite_ref-Lenovo_IdeaCentre_K210_-_TechCrunch_52-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lenovo_IdeaCentre_K210_-_TechCrunch-52">[52]</a></sup> One such feature was Veriface facial recognition technology.<sup id="cite_ref-Lenovo_IdeaCentre_K210_-_TechCrunch_52-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lenovo_IdeaCentre_K210_-_TechCrunch-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>At <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_CES&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International CES (page does not exist)">CES</a> 2011, Lenovo announced the launch of four IdeaCentre desktops: the A320, B520, B320, and C205.<sup id="cite_ref-Lenovo_IdeaCentre_Desktops_at_CES_51-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lenovo_IdeaCentre_Desktops_at_CES-51">[51]</a></sup> In the autumn of 2012, the firm introduced the more powerful IdeaCentre A720, with a 27-inch touchscreen display and running Windows 8.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> With a TV tuner and HDMI in, the A720 can also serve as a multimedia hub or home theater PC.<sup id="cite_ref-Lenovo_IdeaCentre_A720_Review_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lenovo_IdeaCentre_A720_Review-54">[54]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2013 Lenovo added a table computer to the IdeaCentre line. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lenovo_IdeaCentre_Horizon_Table_PC&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lenovo IdeaCentre Horizon Table PC (page does not exist)">Lenovo IdeaCentre Horizon Table PC</a>, introduced at the 2013 <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_CES&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International CES (page does not exist)">International CES</a> is a 27-inch tablet computer designed for simultaneous use by multiple people. Thanks to its use of Windows 8 the Horizon can also serve as desktop computer when set upright.<sup id="cite_ref-Table_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Table-55">[55]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="IBM_servers">IBM servers</span></h3>
<p>IBM's Intel based server lines, including <a href="/wiki/IBM_System_x" title="IBM System x">IBM System x</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=IBM_BladeCenter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="IBM BladeCenter (page does not exist)">IBM BladeCenter</a> were sold to Lenovo in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Operations">Operations</span></h2>
<p>Lenovo's principal facilities are in Beijing, <a href="/wiki/Morrisville,_North_Carolina" title="Morrisville, North Carolina">Morrisville, North Carolina</a>  and <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>, with research centers in those locations, as well as <a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shenzhen" title="Shenzhen">Shenzhen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Xiamen" title="Xiamen">Xiamen</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chengdu" title="Chengdu">Chengdu</a> in China, and <a href="/wiki/Yamato,_Kanagawa" title="Yamato, Kanagawa">Yamato in Kanagawa Prefecture</a>, Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> Lenovo operates factories in <a href="/wiki/Chengdu" title="Chengdu">Chengdu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hefei" title="Hefei">Hefei</a> in <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>, and as of December 2011 has plans to start production in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Argentina (page does not exist)">Argentina</a>.  A 7,500 square foot <a href="/w/index.php?title=Flagship_store&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Flagship store (page does not exist)">flagship store</a> opened in Beijing in February 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-einhorn2013_16-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-einhorn2013-16">[16]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%E8%81%94%E6%83%B3.jpg" title="File:联想.jpg">File:联想.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Lenovo R&amp;D centre in Shenzhen, China</div></div></div>
<p>Lenovo's manufacturing operations are a departure from the usual industry practice of outsourcing to contract manufacturers. Lenovo instead focuses on <a href="/wiki/Vertical_integration" title="Vertical integration">vertical integration</a> in order to avoid excessive reliance on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Original_equipment_manufacturers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Original equipment manufacturers (page does not exist)">original equipment manufacturers</a> and to keep down costs.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> Speaking on this topic, Yang Yuanqing said, "Selling PCs is like selling fresh fruit. The speed of innovation is very fast, so you must know how to keep up with the pace, control inventory, to match supply with demand and handle very fast turnover." Lenovo benefited from its vertical integration after flooding affected hard-drive manufacturers in Thailand in 2011, as the company could continue manufacturing operations by shifting production towards products for which hard drives were still available.<sup id="cite_ref-WARC_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WARC-59">[59]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-WS_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WS-60">[60]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lenovo began to emphasize vertical integration after a meeting in 2009 in which CEO Yang Yuanqing, and the head of Lenovo's supply chain, analyzed the costs versus the benefits of in-house manufacturing, and decided to make at least 50% of Lenovo's manufacturing in-house. Lenovo Chief Technology Officer George He said that vertical integration is having an important role in product development. He stated, "If you look at the industry trends, most innovations for" PCs, smartphones, tablets and smart TVs are related to innovation of key components—display, battery and storage. Differentiation of key parts is so important. So we started investing more...and working very closely with key parts suppliers."<sup id="cite_ref-WS_60-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WS-60">[60]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2012, Lenovo partially moved production of its ThinkPad line of computers to Japan. ThinkPads will be produced by NEC in <a href="/wiki/Yamagata_Prefecture" title="Yamagata Prefecture">Yamagata Prefecture</a>. Akaemi Watanabe, president of Lenovo Japan, said, "As a Japanese, I am glad to see the return to domestic production and the goal is to realize full-scale production as this will improve our image and make the products more acceptable to Japanese customers.”<sup id="cite_ref-WS_60-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WS-60">[60]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-SOFT_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SOFT-61">[61]</a></sup>
</p><p>In October 2012, Lenovo announced that it would start assembling computers in <a href="/wiki/Whitsett,_North_Carolina" title="Whitsett, North Carolina">Whitsett</a>, <a href="/wiki/North_Carolina" title="North Carolina">North Carolina</a>. Production of desktop and laptop computers, including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=ThinkPad_Helix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="ThinkPad Helix (page does not exist)">ThinkPad Helix</a> began in January 2013. As of July 2013, 115 workers were employed at this facility. Lenovo has been in Whitsett since 2008, where it also has centers for logistics, customer service, and return processing.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup>  
</p><p>Lenovo products have been banned by spy and defense agencies in some countries over spying concerns.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Corporate_affairs">Corporate affairs</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lenovo_Beijing_R%26D_Campus.JPG" title="File:Lenovo Beijing R&amp;D Campus.JPG">File:Lenovo Beijing R&amp;D Campus.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Lenovo corporate campus in Beijing</div></div></div>
<p>The company executive headquarters are in <a href="/wiki/Morrisville,_North_Carolina" title="Morrisville, North Carolina">Morrisville, North Carolina</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Lenovocontact_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lenovocontact-65">[65]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> near <a href="/wiki/Raleigh,_North_Carolina" title="Raleigh, North Carolina">Raleigh</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Research_Triangle" title="Research Triangle">Research Triangle</a> metropolitan area,<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-McGregor204_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McGregor204-68">[68]</a></sup> As of October 2012, the facility has about 2,000 employees.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> Lenovo identifies its facilities in Morrisville, Beijing, and Singapore as its "key location addresses,"<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> where its principal operations occur.<sup id="cite_ref-Lenovocontact_65-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lenovocontact-65">[65]</a></sup> The company stated that "[b]y foregoing a traditional headquarters model and focusing on centers of excellence around the world, Lenovo makes the maximum use of its resources to create the best products in the most efficient and effective way possible."<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> The company <a href="/w/index.php?title=Registered_office&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Registered office (page does not exist)">registered office</a> is on the 23rd floor of the Lincoln House building of the <a href="/wiki/TaiKoo_Place" title="TaiKoo Place">TaiKoo Place</a> in <a href="/wiki/Quarry_Bay" title="Quarry Bay">Quarry Bay</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup>
</p><p>Previously the company's U.S. headquarters were in <a href="/wiki/Purchase,_New_York" title="Purchase, New York">Purchase</a>, <a href="/wiki/Harrison,_New_York" title="Harrison, New York">Harrison, New York</a>. About 70 people worked there. In 2006, Lenovo announced that it was consolidating its U.S. headquarters, a logistics facility in <a href="/wiki/Boulder,_Colorado" title="Boulder, Colorado">Boulder, Colorado</a>, and a call center in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Atlanta,_Georgia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Atlanta, Georgia (page does not exist)">Atlanta, Georgia</a> to a new facility in Morrisville. The company received offers of over $11 million in incentive funds from the local Morrisville, NC area and from the State of North Carolina on the condition that the company employs about 2,200 people.<sup id="cite_ref-Hogan1_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hogan1-73">[73]</a></sup> If the company failed to employ that amount, it would not acquire the incentives.<sup id="cite_ref-Hogan2_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hogan2-74">[74]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Financials_and_market_share">Financials and market share</span></h3>
<p>Lenovo is the dominant supplier of computers in mainland China and became the world's second-largest supplier of <a href="/wiki/Personal_computers" title="Personal computers" class="mw-redirect">personal computers</a> during the third quarter of 2011. Lenovo held around 13.5% of the worldwide computer market as of October 2011. The company's expansion was boosted in part by a joint venture with <a href="/wiki/NEC" title="NEC">NEC</a> in <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a> and aggressive marketing to both professionals and consumers. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yang_Yuanqing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yang Yuanqing (page does not exist)">Yang Yuanqing</a> said that Lenovo would continue its expansion by focusing on technological convergence in the areas of smart phones, tablets, personal computers, and "smart TV." "We must deliver a great user experience across all platforms to achieve our goal and become the leading personal technology company in the world," he said.
</p><p>In the second quarter of 2011, Lenovo was the world's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Market_share_of_personal_computer_vendors&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Market share of personal computer vendors (page does not exist)">third-largest vendor</a> of personal computers.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> For the year ending with third quarter 2010, its market share increased from 8.6 percent to 10.4 percent.<sup id="cite_ref-Ranii_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ranii-76">[76]</a></sup> The company is the largest seller of PCs in China, with a 28.6% share of the China market, according to research firm IDC in July 2009. It reported annual sales of $14.9 billion for the fiscal year ending 2008/2009 (ending March 31, 2009).
</p><p>During the first quarter of 2011, Lenovo held 31.7% of the personal computer market in China when measured by units sold. Lenovo reported a 98.3 percent rise in profit to $108.8 million during the first quarter of 2011, up from $54.86 million during the same quarter of the previous year. Lenovo shipped 10.28 million personal computers in the first quarter of 2011. Lenovo reported a 54-percent rise in profit for the third quarter of 2011, beating analyst predictions, in spite of slow sales growth and a shortage of hard drives.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup>
</p><p>From March 4, 2013 Lenovo was included as a constituent stock in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hang_Seng_Index&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hang Seng Index (page does not exist)">Hang Seng Index</a>. Lenovo replaced the unprofitable <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aluminum_Corp_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aluminum Corp of China (page does not exist)">Aluminum Corp of China</a>, a state-owned enterprise, on the list of 50 key companies on the Hong Kong stock exchange that constitute the Hang Seng Index. The inclusion of Lenovo and Tencent, China's largest internet firm, significantly increased the weight of the technology sector on the index. Being added to the Hang Seng Index was a significant boon for Lenovo and its shareholders as it widened the pool of investors willing to purchase Lenovo's stock. For instance, index funds pegged to the Hang Seng and pension funds that consider index inclusion now have the opportunity to invest in Lenovo.<sup id="cite_ref-SCMP22_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SCMP22-78">[78]</a></sup> On November 2013 it was reported that Lenovo achieved double digit market share in the United States for the first time.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ownership">Ownership</span></h3>
<p>As of 1 October 2011, 58% of Lenovo stock was held by the general public, 34% by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Legend_Holdings_Limited&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Legend Holdings Limited (page does not exist)">Legend Holdings Limited</a>, and 8% by other entities. The <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Chinese Academy of Sciences">Chinese Academy of Sciences</a> owns 36% of Legend Holdings.<sup id="cite_ref-Investor_fact_sheet_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Investor_fact_sheet-80">[80]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 4 September 2009, Oceanwide Holdings Group, a private <a href="/w/index.php?title=Investment_firm&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Investment firm (page does not exist)">investment firm</a> based in Beijing, bought 29% of Legend Holdings, the parent company of Lenovo, for 2.76 billion yuan.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup>
</p><p>Responding to claims that Lenovo is a <a href="/wiki/State_owned_enterprise" title="State owned enterprise" class="mw-redirect">state owned enterprise</a> CEO Yang Yuanqing said: "Our company is a 100% market oriented company. Some people have said we are a state owned enterprise. It's 100% not true. In 1984 the Chinese Academy of Sciences only invested $25,000 in our company. The purpose of the Chinese Academy of Sciences to invest in this company was that they wanted to commercialize their research results. The Chinese Academy of Sciences is a pure research entity in China, owned by the government. From this point, you could say we're different from state-owned enterprises. Secondly, after this investment, this company is run totally by the founders and management team. The government has never been involved in our daily operation, in important decisions, strategic direction, nomination of the CEO and top executives and financial management. Everything is done by our management team."<sup id="cite_ref-state_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-state-82">[82]</a></sup>
</p><p>Yang dramatically increased his ownership stake in by acquiring 797 million shares in 2011. As of  June 2011, Yang owned an 8 percent stake in Lenovo. He previously owned only 70 million shares. In a statement, Yang said, "While the transaction is a personal financial matter, I want to be very clear that my decision to make this investment is based on my strong belief in the company's very bright future. Our culture is built on commitment and ownership&#160;– we do what we say, and we own what we do. My decision to increase my holdings represents my steadfast belief in these principles."<sup id="cite_ref-ownership_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ownership-83">[83]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Corporate_culture">Corporate culture</span></h3>
<p>Lenovo's corporate culture differs significantly from most large Chinese companies. While Lenovo was founded using seed capital from the state-owned <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Chinese Academy of Sciences">Chinese Academy of Sciences</a>, Lenovo is run as a private enterprise with little or no interference by the state. Lenovo's senior executives, including many non-Chinese, rotate between two head offices, one in Beijing and the other in Morrisville, North Carolina, and Lenovo's research and development center in Japan. Two Westerners have served as Lenovo's CEO.<sup id="cite_ref-Econ1_43-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Econ1-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p><p>English is Lenovo's official language. Lenovo's CEO, Yang Yuanqing, initially did not understand English well, but relocated his family to Morrisville in order to improve his language skills and soak up American culture. One American Lenovo executive interviewed by <i>The Economist</i> praised Yang for his efforts to make Lenovo a friendly place for foreigners to work. He said that Yang had created a "performance culture" in place of the traditional Chinese work style of "waiting to see what the emperor wants."<sup id="cite_ref-Econ1_43-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Econ1-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p><p>When Yang took over Lenovo's personal computer division, he strongly discouraged the use of formal titles and required staff to address each other by their given names. Yang even required managers to stand outside their offices each morning to greet their employees while carrying signs with their first names. When Yang's division moved to a new building in 1997, he used the move to break Lenovo's cultural links to the past by insisting on a more formal dress code and training all employees in telephone etiquette; Yang wanted his people to think and act like high-tech workers in developed markets.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Leadership">Leadership</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Yang_Yuanqing">Yang Yuanqing</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Yang_Yuanqing.jpeg" title="File:Yang Yuanqing.jpeg">File:Yang Yuanqing.jpeg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Yang Yuanqing, Lenovo's Chairman and CEO</div></div></div>
<p>Yang Yuanqing is the chairman and chief executive officer of Lenovo. One of his major achievements was leading Lenovo to become the best-selling personal computer brand in China since 1997. In 2001, <i><a href="/wiki/Business_Week" title="Business Week" class="mw-redirect">Business Week</a></i> named him one of Asia's rising stars in business.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> Yang was president and CEO of Lenovo until 2004, when Lenovo closed its acquisition of IBM's PC division, afterward Yang was succeeded as Lenovo CEO by IBM's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Steve_Ward_(businessman)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Steve Ward (businessman) (page does not exist)">Stephen M. Ward, Jr.</a> Ward was succeeded by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bill_Amelio&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bill Amelio (page does not exist)">Bill Amelio</a> on December 20, 2005. On February 2009, Yang replaced Amelio as CEO and has served in that capacity ever since. Yang was chairman of Lenovo's board from 2004 to 2008, and returned as chairman in 2012 alongside his role as CEO. 
</p><p>In 2012, Yang received a $3 million bonus as a reward for record profits, which he in-turn redistributed to about 10,000 of Lenovo's employees. According to Lenovo spokesman, Jeffrey Shafer, Yang felt that it would be the right thing to, “redirect [the money] to the employees as a real tangible gesture for what they done.” Shafer also said that Yang, who owns about eight percent of Lenovo's stock, "felt that he was rewarded well simply as the owner of the company.”<sup id="cite_ref-Bonus_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bonus-85">[85]</a></sup> The bonuses were mostly distributed among staff working in positions such as production and reception who received an average of 2,000 yuan or about US$314. This was almost equivalent to a monthly salary of an average worker in China.<sup id="cite_ref-WPBlog_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WPBlog-86">[86]</a></sup> Yang made a similar gift of $3.25 million again in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-Huff_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Huff-87">[87]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Lenovo's annual report, Yang earned $14 million, including $5.2 million in bonuses, during the fiscal year that ended in March 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-CNNBonus_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNNBonus-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2013, <i>Barron's</i> named Yang one of the "World's Best CEOs." <sup id="cite_ref-Best_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Best-89">[89]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Liu_Chuanzhi">Liu Chuanzhi</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Liu Chuanzhi is the founder and chairman of Lenovo. Liu was trained as an engineer at a military college and later went on to work at the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Chinese Academy of Sciences">Chinese Academy of Sciences</a>. Like many young people during the Cultural Revolution, Liu was denounced and sent to the countryside where he worked as a laborer on a rice farm.
</p><p>Liu claims <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hewlett-Packard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hewlett-Packard (page does not exist)">Hewlett-Packard</a> as a key source of inspiration. In an interview with <i><a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">The Economist</a></i> he stated that "Our earliest and best teacher was Hewlett-Packard." For more than ten years, Lenovo was Hewlett-Packard's distributor in China.<sup id="cite_ref-Economist_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economist-90">[90]</a></sup> In reference to Lenovo's later acquisition of IBM's personal computer unit Liu said, "I remember the first time I took part in a meeting of IBM agents. I was wearing an old business suit of my father's and I sat in the back row. Even in my dreams, I never imagined that one day we could buy the IBM PC business. It was unthinkable. Impossible."<sup id="cite_ref-chief_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chief-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Board_of_directors">Board of directors</span></h4>
<p>In early 2013, Lenovo announced the addition of Yahoo founder <a href="/wiki/Jerry_Yang_(entrepreneur)" title="Jerry Yang (entrepreneur)">Jerry Yang</a> to its board. Lenovo's CEO Yang Yuanqing said, ""Jerry’s appointment as an observer to our board furthers Lenovo’s reputation as a transparent international company." Just prior to the appointment of Jerry Yang, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tudor_Brown&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tudor Brown (page does not exist)">Tudor Brown</a> the founder of British semiconductor design firm <a href="/w/index.php?title=ARM_Holdings&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="ARM Holdings (page does not exist)">ARM</a>, was also appointed to Lenovo's board. Speaking of both men Yang Yuanqing said, "We believe that they will add a great deal to our strategic thinking, long-term direction and, ultimately, our ability to achieve our aspirations in the PC plus era."
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Marketing_and_sponsorships">Marketing and sponsorships</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Emerging_markets">Emerging markets</span></h3>
<p>In 2009 Lenovo became the first personal computer manufacturer to divide countries into emerging markets, such as China, India, and Brazil, and mature markets, such as the United States, Japan, and Europe. Lenovo then developed a different set of strategies for each category. This approach has now been widely adopted among Lenovo's competitors.<sup id="cite_ref-People_9-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-People-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2012, Lenovo made a major effort to expand its market share in developing economies such as Brazil and India through acquisitions and increased budgets for marketing and advertising. While Lenovo has not revealed its total spending on marketing, it did increase marketing and advertising expenditures by $248 million in the fiscal year ending in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-Econ1_43-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Econ1-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="China">China</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:A_Lenovo_Store_in_China.jpg" title="File:A Lenovo Store in China.jpg">File:A Lenovo Store in China.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A Lenovo Store in China</div></div></div>
<p>In China, Lenovo has a vast distribution network designed to make sure that there is at least one shop selling Lenovo computers within 50 kilometers of nearly all consumers. Lenovo has also developed close relationships with its Chinese distributors, who are granted exclusive territories and only carry Lenovo products.<sup id="cite_ref-Econ1_43-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Econ1-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of July 2013, Lenovo believes that urbanization initiatives being pushed by Premier <a href="/wiki/Li_Keqiang" title="Li Keqiang">Li Keqiang</a> will allow it to sustain sales growth in mainland China for the foreseeable future. Speaking of Lenovo’s prospects on the mainland at its annual general meeting in Hong Kong in 2013, Yang Yuanqing said: “I believe urbanisation will help us further increase the overall [domestic] PC market.”  Yang also stressed the opportunity presented by the China's relatively low penetration rate of personal computers. Lenovo previously benefited from the Chinese government’s rural subsidy, part of a wider economic stimulus initiative, designed to increase purchases of appliances and electronics. That program of subsidies, which Lenovo joined in 2004, ended in 2011. Lenovo enjoys consistent price premiums over its traditional competitors in rural markets and a stronger local sales and service presence.<sup id="cite_ref-FT2_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FT2-91">[91]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="India">India</span></h4>
<p>Lenovo has gained significant market share in India through bulk orders to large companies and government agencies. For example, the government of <a href="/wiki/Tamil_Nadu" title="Tamil Nadu">Tamil Nadu</a> ordered a million laptops from Lenovo in 2012 and single-handedly made the firm a market leader. Lenovo distributes most of the personal computers it sells in India through five national distributors such as <a href="/wiki/Ingram_Micro" title="Ingram Micro">Ingram Micro</a> and Redington.<sup id="cite_ref-India6_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-India6-92">[92]</a></sup>
</p><p>Given that most smartphones and tablets are sold to individuals Lenovo is pursuing a different strategy making use of many small state-centric distributors. Amar Babu, Lenovo's managing director for India, said, "To reach out to small towns and the hinterland, we have tied up with 40 regional distributors. We want our regional distributors to be exclusive to us. We will, in turn, ensure they have exclusive rights to distribute Lenovo products in their catchment area." <sup id="cite_ref-India6_92-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-India6-92">[92]</a></sup> As of 2013, Lenovo had about 6,000 retailers selling smartphones and tablets in India. In February 2013, Lenovo established a relationship with Reliance Communications to sell smartphones. The smartphones carried by Reliance have dual-SIM capability and support both GSM and CDMA. Babu claims that the relative under-penetration of smartphones in India represents an opportunity for Lenovo.<sup id="cite_ref-India6_92-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-India6-92">[92]</a></sup>
</p><p>In India, where Lenovo is relatively unknown, Lenovo grants distributors exclusive territories, but allows them to sell computers from other companies. Lenovo uses its close relationships with distributors to gain market intelligence and speed up product development.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Africa">Africa</span></h4>
<p>Lenovo plans to release its smartphones in Nigeria in the second half of 2013 in an effort to find markets where it can sell directly to consumers. Lenovo specifically picked Nigeria, because unlike South Africa and other African countries, there is no requirement to partner with a local telecom firm to sell its phones. Nigeria is Africa's second-largest economy after South Africa. Lenovo will sell its phones across as many as six price segments with the most expensive selling for about US$500. Lenovo says it is investigating the rest of Africa and that Egypt will be its next target for expansion.<sup id="cite_ref-Africa1_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Africa1-93">[93]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="United_States">United States</span></h3>
<p>In the United States, Lenovo began the "For Those Who Do" marketing campaign in 2010, created by the ad agency <a href="/wiki/Saatchi_%26_Saatchi" title="Saatchi &amp; Saatchi">Saatchi &amp; Saatchi</a>. The campaign was Lenovo's first to go global, with the exception of its domestic market in China, where it retained its existing "Imagine" (lian xiang) slogan. The campaign did not reach China because "do" carries connotations of physical work in the country, an image that Lenovo did not want attached to their brand.<sup id="cite_ref-fc_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fc-94">[94]</a></sup> "For Those Who Do" was designed to appeal to young consumers in the 18-to 25-year-old demographic by stressing its utility to creative individuals that Lenovo's advertising refers to as "doers".<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ashton_Kutcher">Ashton Kutcher</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In October 2013 Lenovo announced that it had hired Ashton Kutcher as a product engineer and spokesman. Kutcher announced Lenovo's Yoga Tablet at a media event the same month; He flew to China to meet with Lenovo executives shortly after. David Roman, Lenovo's chief marketing officer, said, "His partnership goes beyond traditional bounds by deeply integrating him into our organization as a product engineer. Ashton will help us break new ground by challenging assumptions, bringing new perspective and contributing his technical expertise to Yoga Tablet and other devices." Kutcher co-founded A-Grade Investments, an investor in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Airbnb&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Airbnb (page does not exist)">Airbnb</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Foursquare&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Foursquare (page does not exist)">Foursquare</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spotify&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spotify (page does not exist)">Spotify</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Path_(social_network)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Path (social network) (page does not exist)">Path</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uber_(company)" title="Uber (company)">Uber</a> and other technology firms. Kutcher studied <a href="/wiki/Biochemical_engineering" title="Biochemical engineering">biochemical engineering</a> at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Iowa" title="University of Iowa">University of Iowa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ash_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ash-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Kobe_Bryant">Kobe Bryant</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Kobe Bryant appeared in ads aired in China and other Asian countries for the K900 smartphone in 2013. <sup id="cite_ref-NYT2_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT2-97">[97]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Olympics">Olympics</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Official_2008_Summer_Olympics_Torch_in_Vilnius.jpg" title="File:Official 2008 Summer Olympics Torch in Vilnius.jpg">File:Official 2008 Summer Olympics Torch in Vilnius.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The 2008 Summer Olympics Torch, which was designed by Lenovo</div></div></div>
<p>Lenovo was an official computer sponsor of the <a href="/wiki/2006_Winter_Olympics" title="2006 Winter Olympics">2006 Winter Olympics</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Turin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Turin (page does not exist)">Turin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">2008 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beijing (page does not exist)">Beijing</a>. When asked about Lenovo's brand Yang Yuanqing said, "The Beijing Olympics were very good for brand awareness in countries like the US and Argentina, but not good enough."<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="YouTube_Space_Lab">YouTube Space Lab</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
On December 2011, Lenovo announced the YouTube Space Lab contest in conjunction with <a href="/w/index.php?title=YouTube&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="YouTube (page does not exist)">YouTube</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=NASA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NASA (page does not exist)">NASA</a>, the <a href="/wiki/European_Space_Agency" title="European Space Agency">European Space Agency</a>, and <a href="/wiki/JAXA" title="JAXA">JAXA</a>, allowing students between the ages of 14 and 18 the chance to devise experiments to be performed by astronauts on the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a>. The global winners received a trip to Japan or Russia in addition to having their experiment results live-streamed from space.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="NFL">NFL</span></h3>
<p>In July 2012, Lenovo and the <a href="/wiki/National_Football_League" title="National Football League">National Football League</a> (NFL) announced that Lenovo had become the NFL's "Official Laptop, Desktop and Workstation Sponsor." Lenovo said that this was its largest sponsorship deal ever in the United States. Lenovo will receive advertising space in NFL venues and events and be allowed to use the NFL logo on its products and ads. Lenovo said that this sponsorship would boost its efforts to market to the key 18-to-35-year-old male demographic.
</p><p>The NFL has been a Lenovo customer since 2007 and the sponsorship resulted from that relationship. NFL stars <a href="/wiki/Jerry_Rice" title="Jerry Rice">Jerry Rice</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=DeAngelo_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="DeAngelo Williams (page does not exist)">DeAngelo Williams</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Torry_Holt" title="Torry Holt">Torry Holt</a> were on hand for the announcement and a celebration with 1,500 Lenovo employees. Lenovo's sponsorship will last at least three years.<sup id="cite_ref-NFL_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NFL-100">[100]</a></sup>
</p>
